questions.text: Bacteria with safety pin appearance?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vibrio parahemolyticus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The safety pin appearance, or bipolar staining, is observed in specific bacteria like Vibrio parahaemolyticus, Yersinia pestis, and others identified by the mnemonic "Can Produce Very High Yield." This unique staining pattern is due to stain accumulation at the poles of the bacterial cell.

questions.text: An HIV patient with fever, chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined which showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool?

options.label: A
options.text: Diluted Carbol Fuchsin, 20% H 2 S0 4 and Methylene blue

options.label: B
options.text: Strong Carbol Fuchsin, 1% H 2 S0 4 and Loeffler’s methylene blue

options.label: C
options.text: Strong Carbol Fuchsin, 1 % H 2 S0 4 , iodine and methylene blue

options.label: D
options.text: Diluted Carbol Fuchsin, 5% H 2 SO 4 and methylene blue

questions.correct_answer: B. Strong Carbol Fuchsin, 1% H 2 S0 4 and Loeffler’s methylene blue
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Strong Carbol Fuchsin, 1% H2S04and Loeffler’s methylene blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sporozoites (Cyclospora, Isospora, Cryptosporidium) causing diarrhea in HIV patients are identified using acid-fast staining with 1% H2SO4 as the decolorizer, in contrast to the standard 20% H2SO4 used for most acid-fast organisms.
  • ➤ 1% H2SO4

questions.text: In negative staining?

options.label: A
options.text: The structure to be -demonstrated is stained

options.label: B
options.text: The structure to be demonstrated is not stained

options.label: D
options.text: The background and structure are stained

questions.correct_answer: B. The structure to be demonstrated is not stained
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The structure to be demonstrated is not stained

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Negative staining involves staining the background while leaving the structure (such as bacteria or capsules) unstained. It is particularly useful for visualizing capsulated bacteria and spirochetes.

questions.text: Spore forming anaerobic gram positive bacilli:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clostridia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clostridium is the only bacterium that fulfills all three criteria: it is gram-positive, spore-forming, and anaerobic.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: Peritrichous flagellae are seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Proteus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peritrichous flagella, characterized by flagella distributed across the entire bacterial surface, are seen in highly motile bacteria such as Proteus.

questions.text: Difference between gram + ve and gram -ve organism is that Gram +ve org. contains?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Teichoic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Teichoic acid is a distinguishing feature of gram-positive bacteria and is absent in gram-negative bacteria, making it a key identifier in bacterial classification.
  • ➤ Teichoic acid

questions.text: Sterilization by hot air oven is carried out at:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 160°C x 2 hour

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ideal sterilization setting for a hot air oven is 160°C for 2 hours , which ensures complete elimination of microorganisms, including spores.
  • ➤ 160°C for 2 hours

questions.text: Biological indicator used to determine the efficiency of moist heat sterilization in an autoclave is, the spores of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bacillus stearothermophilus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For moist heat sterilization in an autoclave, the biological indicator used is the spores of Bacillus stearothermophilus , which confirm the sterilization’s efficacy.
  • ➤ Bacillus stearothermophilus

questions.text: All the following statements are true regarding endotoxins except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neutralized by specific antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endotoxins, unlike exotoxins, are heat-stable, poorly antigenic, and not neutralized by specific antibodies. The statement that endotoxins are "neutralized by specific antibodies" is incorrect.

questions.text: The following pathogen does not satisfy "Koch’s postulates“?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lepra bacilli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Koch’s postulates are foundational for establishing disease causation, but they have limitations. Mycobacterium leprae is a key exception, as it cannot be cultured in artificial media or fulfill all postulates.

questions.text: Technique of sterilization was introduced by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Louis Pasteur

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Louis Pasteur introduced the technique of sterilization, along with significant contributions to microbiology, including pasteurization, vaccine development, and germ theory of disease.

questions.text: Loffler’s medium is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Enriched medium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Löffler’s medium is an enriched medium containing serum, used primarily for cultivating Corynebacterium diphtheriae and other fastidious organisms.
  • ➤ enriched medium

questions.text: True regarding lag phase is?

options.label: A
options.text: Time taken to adapt in the new environment

options.label: C
options.text: The plateau in lag phase is due to cell death

options.label: D
options.text: It is the 2nd phase in bacterial growth curve

questions.correct_answer: A. Time taken to adapt in the new environment
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Time taken to adapt in the new environment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lag phase represents the time taken by bacteria to adapt to a new environment, with active metabolic activity but no cell division.

questions.text: Which one of the following bacteria is classified as Obligate anaerobe?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Clostridia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clostridia is an obligate anaerobe, unable to survive in the presence of oxygen, unlike the other bacteria listed.

questions.text: DNA is detected by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Southern blot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA is detected using the Southern blot , a technique developed specifically for this purpose.
  • ➤ Southern blot

questions.text: Nontoxigenic C. diphtheriae changes to toxigenic C. diphtheriae by the help of bacteriophage by which method this conversion occur?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Transduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The conversion of nontoxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae to toxigenic strains occurs through transduction , a process mediated by bacteriophages that transfer the toxigenic gene from one bacterium to another.
  • ➤ transduction

questions.text: Superantigens are produced by all the following pathogens, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Enterococcus faecalis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superantigens are produced by certain bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes), viruses (e.g., HIV, Rabies virus), and fungi (e.g., Malassezia furfur). Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens.
  • ➤ Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens.

questions.text: Variable portion of antibody molecule is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) N-Terminal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The variable portion of an antibody is located at the N-terminal region , and it is critical for antigen recognition and binding. The constant region, located at the C-terminal, mediates effector functions and remains unchanged for a given antibody class.
  • ➤ variable portion of an antibody is located at the N-terminal region

questions.text: Which antibody crosses placenta:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IgG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgG is the only antibody that crosses the placenta, providing passive immunity to the fetus. Be attentive to variations in the question, such as whether it asks about antibodies provided by the mother (IgG) or those first synthesized by the fetus (IgM).
  • ➤ IgG is the only antibody that crosses the placenta, providing passive immunity to the fetus.

questions.text: Rose Waaler test:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Passive haemagglutination test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Rose Waaler test is an example of passive haemagglutination , where RBCs are used as carriers for soluble antigens to detect specific antibodies in serum.
  • ➤ Rose Waaler test
  • ➤ passive haemagglutination

questions.text: Precipitation in comparison to agglutination requires:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Soluble antigen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Precipitation requires soluble antigens , which form visible complexes when interacting with antibodies, distinguishing it from agglutination that involves particulate antigens.
  • ➤ Precipitation requires soluble antigens

questions.text: C3 convertase in alternate complement pathway:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C3bBb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the alternate complement pathway, the C3 convertase is C3bBb , which plays a critical role in cleaving C3 and amplifying the immune response.
  • ➤ C3 convertase is C3bBb

questions.text: B cell mediated hypersensitivity reaction is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Arthus phenomenon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Arthus phenomenon is a B cell-mediated Type III hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by immune complex formation and complement activation. Other options listed are examples of T cell-mediated Type IV hypersensitivity reactions.
  • ➤ Arthus phenomenon

questions.text: Deficiency of both T and B Lymphocyte involved in all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis involves a deficiency in T cells only , not in both T and B lymphocytes. The other options represent combined immunodeficiency disorders affecting both lymphocyte types.
  • ➤ Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • ➤ T cells only

questions.text: Best example of syngeneic graft:

options.label: C
options.text: Between two members of same or different species

options.label: D
options.text: Between two sites of same person

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Between monozygotic twins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A syngeneic graft is the best example of a transplant between monozygotic twins , where the genetic makeup is identical, ensuring no rejection.
  • ➤ syngeneic graft
  • ➤ monozygotic twins

questions.text: An anaerobe causing multiple abscess with dischargiung sinus, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus are used to diagnose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Actinomycetes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Actinomycetes is an anaerobic bacterium causing actinomycosis, characterized by multiple discharging sinuses, abscesses, and sulfur granules in pus. Differentiating between Actinomycetes and Nocardia requires attention to oxygen requirements and acid-fast staining.
  • ➤ Actinomycetes is an anaerobic bacterium causing actinomycosis, characterized by multiple discharging sinuses, abscesses, and sulfur granules in pus.

questions.text: Inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin stab is characteristic of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bacillus anthracis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inverted fir tree appearance in a gelatin stab is a distinguishing characteristic of Bacillus anthracis , caused by its obligate aerobic nature leading to maximum liquefaction at the surface of the medium.
  • ➤ inverted fir tree appearance
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria act by increasing c-AMP:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bordetella pertussis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bacterial toxins that act by increasing cyclic AMP (c-AMP) include Bordetella pertussis , Vibrio cholerae , Bacillus anthracis , and ETEC (heat-labile toxin) .
  • ➤ increasing cyclic AMP (c-AMP)
  • ➤ Bordetella pertussis
  • ➤ Vibrio cholerae
  • ➤ Bacillus anthracis
  • ➤ ETEC (heat-labile toxin)
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ There are two primary mechanisms by which bacterial toxins affect human cells:
  • ➤ Inhibiting Protein Synthesis : These toxins target the ribosome and inhibit elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis. The mnemonic for these bacteria is DPSS (Delhi Public Secondary School) : D - Diphtheria toxin (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) P - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Exotoxin A) S - Shiga toxin (Shigella dysenteriae) S - Shiga-like toxin (produced by enterohemorrhagic E. coli, EHEC) Increasing c-AMP : These toxins stimulate adenyl cyclase, increasing c-AMP and disrupting cellular ion and water balance, causing cell swelling and lysis. The mnemonic is Be Very Efficient Boy : B - Bordetella pertussis V - Vibrio cholerae E - Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC, heat-labile toxin) B - Bacillus anthracis (edema factor).
  • ➤ Inhibiting Protein Synthesis : These toxins target the ribosome and inhibit elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis. The mnemonic for these bacteria is DPSS (Delhi Public Secondary School) : D - Diphtheria toxin (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) P - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Exotoxin A) S - Shiga toxin (Shigella dysenteriae) S - Shiga-like toxin (produced by enterohemorrhagic E. coli, EHEC)
  • ➤ Inhibiting Protein Synthesis
  • ➤ These toxins target the ribosome and inhibit elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis. The mnemonic for these bacteria is DPSS (Delhi Public Secondary School) : D - Diphtheria toxin (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) P - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Exotoxin A) S - Shiga toxin (Shigella dysenteriae) S - Shiga-like toxin (produced by enterohemorrhagic E. coli, EHEC)
  • ➤ These toxins target the ribosome and inhibit elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis. The mnemonic for these bacteria is DPSS (Delhi Public Secondary School) : D - Diphtheria toxin (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) P - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Exotoxin A) S - Shiga toxin (Shigella dysenteriae) S - Shiga-like toxin (produced by enterohemorrhagic E. coli, EHEC)
  • ➤ DPSS (Delhi Public Secondary School)
  • ➤ D - Diphtheria toxin (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) P - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Exotoxin A) S - Shiga toxin (Shigella dysenteriae) S - Shiga-like toxin (produced by enterohemorrhagic E. coli, EHEC)
  • ➤ D - Diphtheria toxin (Corynebacterium diphtheriae)
  • ➤ D
  • ➤ P - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Exotoxin A)
  • ➤ P
  • ➤ S - Shiga toxin (Shigella dysenteriae)
  • ➤ S
  • ➤ S - Shiga-like toxin (produced by enterohemorrhagic E. coli, EHEC)
  • ➤ S
  • ➤ Increasing c-AMP : These toxins stimulate adenyl cyclase, increasing c-AMP and disrupting cellular ion and water balance, causing cell swelling and lysis. The mnemonic is Be Very Efficient Boy : B - Bordetella pertussis V - Vibrio cholerae E - Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC, heat-labile toxin) B - Bacillus anthracis (edema factor).
  • ➤ Increasing c-AMP
  • ➤ These toxins stimulate adenyl cyclase, increasing c-AMP and disrupting cellular ion and water balance, causing cell swelling and lysis. The mnemonic is Be Very Efficient Boy : B - Bordetella pertussis V - Vibrio cholerae E - Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC, heat-labile toxin) B - Bacillus anthracis (edema factor).
  • ➤ These toxins stimulate adenyl cyclase, increasing c-AMP and disrupting cellular ion and water balance, causing cell swelling and lysis. The mnemonic is Be Very Efficient Boy : B - Bordetella pertussis V - Vibrio cholerae E - Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC, heat-labile toxin) B - Bacillus anthracis (edema factor).
  • ➤ Be Very Efficient Boy
  • ➤ B - Bordetella pertussis V - Vibrio cholerae E - Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC, heat-labile toxin) B - Bacillus anthracis (edema factor).
  • ➤ B - Bordetella pertussis
  • ➤ B
  • ➤ V - Vibrio cholerae
  • ➤ V
  • ➤ E - Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC, heat-labile toxin)
  • ➤ E
  • ➤ B - Bacillus anthracis (edema factor).
  • ➤ B

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of abdominal cramps along with profuse diarrhea. The treating physician wants to process the stool specimen for isolation of Campylobacter jejuni. Which of the following is the method of choice for the culture of stool?

options.label: A
options.text: Culture on TCBS medium incubated at 37°C under aerobic conditions

options.label: B
options.text: Culture on Skirrow’s medium incubated at 42°C under micro-aerophilic conditions

options.label: C
options.text: Culture on MacConkey medium incubated at 42°C under anaerobic conditions

options.label: D
options.text: Culture on Wilson and Blair’s medium incubated at 37°C under micro-aerophilic conditions

questions.correct_answer: B. Culture on Skirrow’s medium incubated at 42°C under micro-aerophilic conditions
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Culture on Skirrow’s medium incubated at 42°C under micro-aerophilic conditions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Campylobacter jejuni is best cultured on Skirrow’s medium at 42°C under micro-aerophilic conditions . Remember the mnemonic Hellboy Camp for micro-aerophilic organisms, which includes Helicobacter, Borrelia, and Campylobacter.
  • ➤ Skirrow’s medium
  • ➤ 42°C under micro-aerophilic conditions
  • ➤ Hellboy Camp

questions.text: Lymphogranuloma venerum is caused by which of the following sexually transmitted agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chlamydia trachomatis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3 , presenting with painless genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (Buboes) . It is distinguishable by its lymphatic system involvement and characteristic clinical features.
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3
  • ➤ painless genital ulcers
  • ➤ painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (Buboes)

questions.text: Tennis racket shape is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cl. tertium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tennis racket shape of terminal, oval spores is characteristic of Clostridium tertium . It is important to distinguish this morphology from the drumstick shape seen in Clostridium tetani , which has terminal, spherical spores.
  • ➤ tennis racket shape
  • ➤ Clostridium tertium
  • ➤ drumstick shape
  • ➤ Clostridium tetani

questions.text: Mechanism of action of botulinum toxin:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inhibition of acetylcholine release

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is inhibition of acetylcholine release , leading to flaccid paralysis . This distinguishes it from tetanus toxin, which inhibits inhibitory neurotransmitters, causing spastic paralysis.
  • ➤ inhibition of acetylcholine release
  • ➤ flaccid paralysis

questions.text: Patient presenting with abdominal pain, diarrhea is taking clindamycin for 5 days. Treated with metronidazole, the symptoms subsided. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Clostridium difficile

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hallmark of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is the development of diarrhea following recent antibiotic use, particularly clindamycin, and the characteristic formation of pseudomembranes in the colon. The preferred treatment is oral vancomycin , with metronidazole as an alternative.
  • ➤ Clostridium difficile infection (CDI)
  • ➤ vancomycin
  • ➤ metronidazole

questions.text: Mechanism of action of toxin produced by the bacterium shown in the figure:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ADP-ribosylation of Elongation factor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The toxin of Corynebacterium diphtheriae acts by ADP-ribosylating Elongation Factor 2 (EF-2) , leading to the inhibition of protein synthesis and subsequent cell death.
  • ➤ Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • ➤ ADP-ribosylating Elongation Factor 2 (EF-2)

questions.text: Sereny test is employed for laboratory diagnosis of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Enteroinvasive E. Coli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sereny test is specific for detecting Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) by demonstrating its ability to invade epithelial cells. A positive Sereny test indicates an invasive strain causing dysentery due to intestinal cell destruction.
  • ➤ Sereny test
  • ➤ Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC)

questions.text: Haemophilus parainfluenzae requires which factors:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Only factor V

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Haemophilus parainfluenzae requires only Factor V (NAD) for growth. Distinguish its growth requirement from other Haemophilus species using the mnemonic provided.
  • ➤ only Factor V (NAD)

questions.text: The colonies grown in MacConkey agar belongs to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Klebsiella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ On MacConkey agar, Klebsiella produces pink mucoid colonies due to lactose fermentation and its capsule. This distinguishes it from other lactose fermenters like E. coli, which produce pink but non-mucoid colonies.
  • ➤ Klebsiella produces pink mucoid colonies

questions.text: Dienes’ phenomena is seen with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proteus mirabilis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dienes’ phenomenon is a unique characteristic of Proteus mirabilis , allowing differentiation of strains based on the merging or separation of swarming patterns on agar plates.
  • ➤ Dienes’ phenomenon
  • ➤ Proteus mirabilis

questions.text: An elderly man presented with fever and cough. Sputum examination revealed gram-negative organisms that were grown on Buffered charcoal yeast extract agar. The organism involved is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Legionella pneumophila

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Legionella pneumophila grows on Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar , which provides specific growth factors like cysteine and iron. The most specific diagnostic clue in this case is the use of BCYE agar for isolation.
  • ➤ Legionella pneumophila
  • ➤ Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar

questions.text: A patient with history of consumption of unpasteurized milk presents with fever. Blood culture reveals gram positive organism with tumbling motility. Most probable disease:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Listeriosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Listeria monocytogenes is the only organism among the options that exhibits tumbling motility and is associated with consumption of unpasteurized milk, making it the most probable cause in this case.
  • ➤ Listeria monocytogenes
  • ➤ tumbling motility

questions.text: In reference to the Mycoplasma, the following are true except:

options.label: B
options.text: They can reproduce in cell free media

options.label: C
options.text: They have an affinity for mammalian cell membranes

options.label: D
options.text: They can pass through filters of 450 nm pore size

questions.correct_answer: A. They are inhibited by penicillin
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) They are inhibited by penicillin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mycoplasma lack a cell wall , making them resistant to penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics. Their unique features include the ability to pass through filters, reproduce in cell-free media, and exhibit affinity for mammalian cell membranes.
  • ➤ Mycoplasma lack a cell wall

questions.text: Selective medium for meningococcal infection is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thayer Martin medium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thayer-Martin medium is the selective medium of choice for isolating Neisseria meningitidis , as it selectively supports Neisseria growth by inhibiting other bacteria and fungi through its antibiotic composition.
  • ➤ Thayer-Martin medium
  • ➤ Neisseria meningitidis

questions.text: Differentiating feature of Neisseria gonococcus from Neisseria meningitidis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Maltose fermentation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The differentiating feature between N. gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis is maltose fermentation . N. meningitidis ferments maltose, while N. gonorrhoeae does not.
  • ➤ N. gonorrhoeae
  • ➤ N. meningitidis
  • ➤ maltose fermentation

questions.text: Pseudomonas exhibits protein synthesis by inhibiting:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) EF-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa inhibits protein synthesis through Exotoxin A , which ADP-ribosylates EF-2 , making it a critical virulence factor.
  • ➤ Exotoxin A
  • ➤ EF-2

questions.text: A 25-year-old boy went for trekking, came with a history of rash. Weil Felix test revealed elevated Ox 2 and Ox 19 titres. What is the most likely organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rickettsia rickettsiae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of elevated OX19 and OX2 titres in a Weil-Felix test strongly indicates a tick-borne spotted fever group infection, most likely caused by Rickettsia rickettsii (Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever) .
  • ➤ OX19 and OX2 titres
  • ➤ tick-borne spotted fever
  • ➤ Rickettsia rickettsii (Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)

questions.text: In a patient with typhoid, diagnosis after 12 days of onset of fever is best done by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Widal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Widal test is the diagnostic method of choice in the second week (7–14 days) of typhoid fever as it detects antibodies against Salmonella typhi.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented to the hospital on the third day of menstruation with complaints of high fever, vomiting and a rash on her trunk and extremities. On investigation she had leucocytosis and a negative blood culture. She is diagnosed as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Toxic shock syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Toxic shock syndrome should be suspected in menstruating women presenting with high fever, vomiting, rash, and systemic signs of infection, especially with tampon use. The causative agent is Staphylococcus aureus, producing toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1).

questions.text: A child presents with infective skin lesion of the leg. Culture was done which showed Gram-positive cocci in chains which were Beta hemolytic colonies. The test to confirm the organism is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bacitracin sensitivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) is the most common cause of infective skin lesions and can be confirmed through bacitracin sensitivity testing.

questions.text: A 9-years old child presented to OPD with complaints of high grade fever, vomiting, one episode of seizure. CSF examination was done and Gram staining of the culture showed the following finding. What is the probable causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Streptococcus pneumonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The identification of Gram-positive diplococci in CSF Gram stain is diagnostic of Streptococcus pneumoniae, a major cause of bacterial meningitis in children.

questions.text: False about mechanism of bacterial toxins:

options.label: A
options.text: Cholera toxin acts by inhibition of guanylcyclase

options.label: C
options.text: Shiga toxin act by inhibiting protein synthesis

options.label: D
options.text: Diphtheria toxin act by inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.correct_answer: A. Cholera toxin acts by inhibition of guanylcyclase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cholera toxin acts by inhibition of guanylcyclase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin increases cAMP levels by stimulating adenyl cyclase, not by inhibiting guanyl cyclase. Shiga and diphtheria toxins inhibit protein synthesis, while botulinum toxin blocks acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction.
  • ➤ Cholera toxin increases cAMP levels by stimulating adenyl cyclase, not by inhibiting guanyl cyclase.
  • ➤ Shiga and diphtheria toxins inhibit protein synthesis, while botulinum toxin blocks acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction.
